review_text: Been using OnePlus 11 for about a week now and at this price range there's no phone right now which can be considered as an overall package.Pros -Extraordinary battery life and even better 100W charging. You'll always appreciate how this makes your life easier when you know you can get your phone charged to 50% in 10 minutes.I don't think I need to review the SoC which is 8gen2. It's not about how super powerful it is but how good it works in terms of efficiency and heating. Though it is start of summer only, I haven't felt gte phone heating up even once. It's like these two problems which ruined last two years Android scene are non existent this time.Display is quite capable with Dolby vision and Dolby Atmos tech, the viewing experience is as immersive as it gets at this price or may be higher.Haptics are awesome, you don't see (feel) haptics as good as this except iphones or pixels.Color OS inspired Oxygen OS is quite good and if we ignore some bugs highlighted by MKBHD. I moved from OnePlus 6 which was maybe pinnacle of OnePlus and Oxygen OS to this and I feel like it's an upgrade.4 years of OS updates and 5 years of security updates. Their updates are not as frequent and useful as Google but this adds to phone's overall life. You can at least get it repaired and have parts replaced in this window. I couldn't get power button replaced on my old OP6 because it was out of support.Camera is decent. It is actually competing with Samsung and iPhones and beating them in low light shots. This is change as OnePlus cameras used to be B+ which is now A- with other flagships at A+ but they also don't come this cheap except pixel. One disappointment is front facing camera. DO NOT BUY THIS PHONE IF YOU'RE A SELFIE LOVER and don't like Vivo and Oppo approach of making your skin look smooth and brighter. Front video is also called at 1080p which is a shame. Should have been 4k30 at least.Cons - as said earlier, there are some annoying bugs/features in UI which can be easily fixed through a small update.Display is not brighter indoor as iphones and Samsung ultras but you won't feel if you haven't seen those.One very apparent disadvantage vis a vis S23 is lack of Wireless charging and IP rating. These are compromises which I think ok to not have if we are getting quad HD display at this price. Although I would have preferred reverse wireless charging so I could charge my earbuds on the go.And last, the most beautiful thing about his phone is it comes with charger and screen guard and a phone case in the box. Appreciate this when trillion dollar companies like Google and Apple don't provide this despite charging more than 1 lakh.I hope you find this helpful. I was criticizing OnePlus and Qualcomm heavily for past two years on all platforms but this is the year they have turned it around.

WHAT A SHOCKER OF A LET DOWN!
review_text: In the family, we had several OnePlus devices, from the earlier ones to the 7 Pro and the 7T.When the company started losing its bearings and direction and moved off from its "flagship killer" tagline, we knew that something was going wrong.  Also, it lost its market share in India, indicating something was amiss.We moved on to phones like the Huawei (still an excellent phone and waiting for the next pro release) and the Apple Series, from the 10, 13, 14 Pro Max, and the Samsung s22 Ultra.  These are highly impressive phones.When the OnePlus was re-launched, with all the Hasselblad stuff and having attended the live launch online, I thought the company was back on track.  Many reviewers spoke/wrote about the speed processor, the refresh rate, and all the hype around the "back on track" phone - I decided to go for it.  At 62,000/- for the 16 GB and 256, I was excited about the prospect of a high-end phone.The first letdown was the horrific camera picture quality. All the phones mentioned earlier far exceed the low-level picture quality of this one. All pictures were lifeless, duds, even in outdoor conditions, and indoors was even worst.  I wonder what Hasselblad's role in all this horrible photo quality is.Many functions were hit-and-miss.  Every time I made a Reel on Instagram with about 25 photos, the App would crash.  It never happened in any other phones I had. Something with hardware or IG, I wouldn't know, but it never happened before.The apps opened fast.  The smoothness was fluidic.  But the colour options, Vivid, Natural, and Pro, were all weird.  Photos downloaded from Cloud, clicked on other phones, looked so different.  But something was lacking; character. I didn't seem to have any feeling of attachment to the product in hand.The slimness was excellent compared to my S22Ultra, and the features were okay.  It looked premium and felt so.  The best battery life. The best charging speed. So many things were good, but...I went back to all the professional reviews in Magazines and online. Many said, "will it sell" and "did it miss a trick" and the height of everyone's remarks was Peter Lau (the founder of One Plus, but now with his company Nothing), who said, "It lacks identity".  That hit the nail right on the head.  An Apple has its identity.  Samsung has its signature.  My friend who owns the Nothing 1 is highly impressed with the natural skin tones of the pictures clicked (no added spice).THE ONEPLUS 11 HAS NO IDENTITY AT ALL.  IT IS A "NOTHING HERE, NO THING THERE" phone.Will it be able to correct its plethora of flaws with future updates?  Or the wrong idea of a camera that went completely wrong, with poor quality results?On a closer look at the picture quality, I saw that it was more of the Oppo type of result.  The skins look plasticy.  Men's skins look makeup-ed.  These were the traits of these early Oppo phones, and people (especially girls) liked the smoothest looks, like baby dolls.Many things are not right with this phone, in spite and despite the latest processor, high Ram and everything else supposedly good.Since there was no return option, and the exchange date was at hand, I thought, I would keep it and give it away to someone not so discerning and would overlook the camera's poor quality.It's gone from me, and no regrets.Will I go the OnePlus route again?  I don't think I want an Oppo Phone.  The good old OnePlus is dead and gone.______________I hope discerning readers will understand what I have said, albeit there may be many positive reviews about this phone.  It's nothing personal towards, OnePlus, but my experience with the OnePlus 11 5G has been a severe letdown.

A below average flagship
review_text: I ordered my One Plus 11 in February 2023 with a lot of excitement as this was my 1st phone purchase after 3.5 years with my iPhone 11. One of the key factors for moving back to Android was the improved UI experience.However, OP 11 is one of the best examples of how the spec sheet doesn't always translate into a great phone in reality. Don't get me wrong OP11 has a lot of pros but also some frustrating cons that ruins the day to day experience. Let me explain below.UI: The Oxygen OS 13 is blazing fast and clutter free but also has loads of bugs, some of these got better with the latest software updates but also some got worse. To start with, the Always On Display doesn't always display the latest notification but repeatedly shows an old message which is absolutely useless. OP 11 didn't come with Android Auto at first but it was added in a software update later but somehow I'm not able to us the same in my car for the last 1 month.Fingerprint Sensor: Optical fingerprint sensor in OP 11 is quick but doesn't work even if your hand is a little sweaty or wet. I miss the rare mounted fingerprint sensor on my OP 5T.Cameras: Camera package sounds impressive looking at the spec sheet but the experience becomes underwhelming due to the poor software processing. Shutter speed is slow compared to my iPhone 11, white balance is inconsistent and human subjects turnout to be unnaturally bright. However, OP 11 takes some of the best nature & portrait shots, you get vivid colors, great HDR output and near perfect edge detection in both the main and 2x cam. Selfie cam takes bland but acceptable pics in daylight.Performance: This is where the spec sheet means business, be it app opening time, multi tasking or graphic intensive games, you're always covered. If performance is your what you're after, you'll never be disappointed.Battery: Battery charging is blazing fast. I get 20% to 100% charging by the time I finish my breakfast and I go through 24 hours before I need to plug it back so I don't care about the lack of wireless charging.I hope they improve the UI and photo processing performance soon as it really has a great hardware package.

title:

A flagship performer without the flagship price.
review_text: Easily one of the best purchases that I have made and well worth its price.Pros:- SD 8 Gen 2 is fast and very power efficient. The performance is indistinguishable in day to day usage when compared to SD 8 Gen 3 on a OnePlus 12 with UFS 4.0. Even though the 12R has a UFS 3.1 storage, you are unlikely to notice any difference whatsoever without running benchmarks or checking the specifications. In real life day to day usage, I have not found any difference and I am a power user who uses a lot of applications and use the phone over 8 Hours a day.- The vapour chamber handles the cooling very well which keeps the device at excellent temperature even when playing games for an extended duration. It almost never goes over 38c.- The display has the same features as the OnePlus 12 (the resolution is relatively lower but it's not noticeable to the naked eye without magnification) and this is one of the best displays that you will come across. The HDR performance is also some of the best I have seen and it is a completely different experience. This can also be seen in the HDR shots taken with cameras. I'd suggest going to a OnePlus experience center and searching for 12K HDR videos on YouTube to get a better idea. Note that the 4,500 nits mentioned is only the HDR brightness at a small white portion of the display under sunlight. This is NOT the max brightness of the full display. But it is bright enough to use under direct sunlight.- Battery life is very impressive with over 8 hours of SOT and the 100W included charger fully charges it in about 35 mins.- Also love that the display can be used even when your hands are wet unlike most other smartphones- The bezels are extremely slim and the chin is smaller than the one on the OnePlus 12. I do wish it was equal all around though.Rather than cons, I'll just mention what it lacks.- Wireless charging- Telephoto cameraThat's pretty much it. If you are looking for a smooth and reliable device with solid performance, battery life, fast charging, decent cameras and display experience, I would easily recommend this. Sure the cameras may not be as good as an iPhone 15 (81k) or a Pixel 8 (83k) but they also cost around 80% more than the OnePlus 12R.
